choices.text: It has surgically implantable titanium fixture
it transmits sound directly to cochlea through the bone conduction using the principle of osseointegration
It is indicated in patients with External Auditory canal atresia
It is not indicated in patients with chronic discharging ear with hearing loss

questions.text: All of the following are true about bone anchored hearing aid except
questions.solution: BAHA- bone anchored hearing aid will be given to hearing impaired individuals where conventional hearing aids can not be given like in bilateral Anotia, EAC atresia, discharging ear, EAC stenosis. Its a specialised device which is surgically fitted partly on to mastoid bone. it transmits sound directly to cochlea through the bone conduction using the principle of osseointegration

choices.text: The vertigo sensation persists for 2-3 hours
Otoconia most commonly migrate to Posterior semicircular canal to cause this entity
There is no hearing loss in this condition
BPPV is the most common cause of peripheral vertigo

questions.text: All are true about benign paroxysmal positional vertigo except
questions.solution:
BPPV

Otoliths or otoconia are calcium carbonate crystals lying embedded in the gelatinous layer of macula. Macula is the sensory end organ of utricle and saccule whose function is linear acceleration.

BPPV

  • Displaced otoconia from macula is the aetiology
  • Most commonly otoliths come to lie in posterior semicircular canal
  • Dix hallpike's test is diagnostic
  • Epley's maneuver Or Semont's maneuver is therapeutic which is particle repositioning maneuver

choices.text: Vestibular evoked myogenic potential is a useful investigation

questions.text: All are characteristic features of superior semicircular canal dehiscence except
questions.solution: Superior semicircular canal dehiscence is either traumatic or congenital. Patient complains of vertigo especially on hearing loud sounds (tullio's phenomenon). Patient shows conductive hearing loss on audiometry due to leakage of sound energy from third window which has been created in SCC (apart from oval and round window). HRCT temporal bone is the diagnostic investigation. Vestibular evoked myogenic potentials (VEMP) is also helpful in its diagnosis.

choices.text: Atticoantral CSOM with Lateral sinus thrombosis

questions.text: Mohan, 22 year old, male gives history of right sided ear discharge, foul smelling and occasionally blood stained for last 6 years. He also complains of hearing loss for last 2 years. For last 3 days patient has developed fever with chills, headache and pallor and oedema over mastoid region. The most probable diagnosis is

Patient has the complaint of right sided hearing loss and left ear hearing is normal.

Tuning fork tests show that Rinne is Negative on right side and positive on left side.

Weber test is lateralised towards left ear.

Absolute bone conduction (ABC) test is normal on left side but decreased on right side. What is the interpretation?
questions.solution:
In this PTA, there is no ac, bc gap which is suggestive of SNHL. AB gap is suggestive of conductive hearing loss.

Dip at 4000 Hz in AC and BC curve in audiogram is suggestive of noise induced hearing loss

Dip at 2000 Hz in BC curve is seen in Otosclerosis (Carhart's Notch)

questions.text:
A 50 year old male patient presenting with hearing loss complaint on left side was subjected to audiometry. His audiogram is shown below

What is the most possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Tuning Fork Test

Tuning fork of 512Hz is ideal. Forks of lower frequency produce sense of bone vibration while those of higher frequency have a shorter decay time

To test AC - A vibratory fork is placed vertically about 2cm away from the opening of EAM

AC tests the function of both conducting mechanism & the cochlea. Normally, hearing through air conduction is louder & heard twice as long as through bone conduction route.

To test BC - Footplate of vibratory fork is placed firmly on the mastoid bone. Cochlea is stimulated directly by vibrations conducted through skull bone. BC is a measure of the cochlear function only

  1. Rinnie Test: In this AC. of the ear is compared with its BC. It is +ve when AC > BC (normal / SN deafness). If -ve Rinne BC > AC in conductive deafness
    1. False -ve rinne : Severe unilateral SNHL. This is prevented by masking the non test ear
  2. Weber Test: Normally, it is heard equally in both ear
    1. Lateralised to the worse ear in conductive deafness. Lateralised to the better ear in SN deafness
  3. Absolute bone conduction (ABC) test: In this patient's bone conduction is compared with that of the examiner. EAM of both patient & examiner should be occluded. In SN deafness, patient hears for a shorter duration

questions.text:
CT scan of neck of a patient of carcinoma larynx has been found to have the involvement of epiglottis, left aryepiglottic fold, left arytenoid, left vocal cord with the invasion of Thyroid cartilage.

What is the ideal treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
This is the stage T4 of cancer larynx as there is involvement of Thyroid cartilage. Therefore total laryngectomy and radiotherapy is required in this case.

The treatment of choice for T3 and T4 cancer larynx is total laryngectomy followed by RT. However, certain cancer study groups recommend the use of concurrent chemoradiation with Cisplatin for T3 cancer larynx as an alternative to total laryngectomy. Though, the 5 year survival rate with concurrent chemoradiation is lower as compared to surgical management.

questions.text:
A patient of T3NoMo carcinoma larynx has undergone total laryngectomy. He has permanent tracheostomy following this surgery. HE is using the device given in picture for vocal rehabilitation.


What is the name of this device?
questions.solution:
Electrolarynx or artificial larynx is a hand held device.


Blom singer prosthesis is a tracheoesophageal puncture device. It is a one way valve surgically placed between trachea and esophagus. It is used for vocal rehabilitation after laryngectomy. It sends air from trachea to esophagus which is used to produce voice. But it does not let the food particles to go from esophagus to trachea so aspiration is not significant

choices.text: Respiratory distress with poor quality of voice

questions.text: A 52 year old female patient underwent total thyroidectomy. While surgery, both side superior laryngeal nerves got damaged. What are the expected post operative symptoms of patient?
questions.solution: SLN supplies cricothyroid and sensory supply to Supraglottis part of larynx. Cricothyroid is tensor muscle which gives quality to voice. So patient have loss of quality of voice and Aspiration.

questions.text: An infant after birth is noticed to have stridor and a hoarse cry. All of the following diagnosis are possible except:
questions.solution:
Laryngomalacia =congenital laryngeal stridor

  • Most common congenital anamoly of larynx
  • Excessive flaccidity of supraglottic larynx, AE folds are weak
  • Inspiratory stridor increases on crying relieved in prone position
  • Cry is normal
  • Fibreoptic laryngoscopy - Omega shaped epiglottis
  • No treatment required. It usually disappears by 2 yrs of age

choices.text: Repeat direct laryngoscopy every hour to assess laryngeal oedema

questions.text: In a patient of acute epiglottitis, all of the following are part of management except
questions.solution: In Acute Epiglottitis, the airway establishment by intubation or tracheostomy is the first treatment to be given. But repeated direct laryngoscopy should be avoided as this can aggravate the edema of larynx,

choices.text: Can be seen in Immunocompetent patients

questions.text: All are true about the entity shown in the CT scan except
questions.solution: Allergic fungal sinusitis is the most common type of fungal sinusitis. The most common organism is Aspergillus fumigates. It is type 1 and 3 allergic reaction to fungal antigens. It has allergic mucin in the nose with nasal polyp formation. These polypi appear heterogenous on CT scan because of fungal colonies into them. The treatment of choice is FESS and steroids. The antifungals are only indicated in invasive variety of fungal sinusitis

questions.text: A wide roomy nasal cavity with thick crust formation and bad odour from nose is seen in
questions.solution:
This case is of Atrophic Rhinitis.

The surgical management of atrophic rhinitis includes -

A.Young's operation:- - Complete Closure of one nostril

B. Modified Young's operation:- - partial closure of both nostrils leaving behind a 3m hole

C. Lautenslager's operation:- Surgical procedures aimed at medializing the lateral nasal wall by injecting Substance like Paraffin, teflon, polythene, cartilage

Rhinoscleroma:

Definition: Chronic, progressive granulomatous infection of nose and upper lip area. This can also involve larynx ( scleroma Larynx)

Organism: Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis (Gram negative: Frisch Bacillus).

It is more common in northern part of India

Clinical Picture:

  1. Atrophic Stage: Atrophic changes occur in the floor of the nose, septum and turbinates
  2. Granulomatous Stage: Subdermal infiltration of the lower part of the external nose and the upper lip (woody feel)
  3. Cicatrical Stage: in this stage due to fibrosis, patient develops cosmetic deformity

Diagnosis:

Submucosal infiltration of plasma cells, lymphocytes, eosinophils, Mikulicz cells & Russel bodies

Mikulicz Cells:

Large foam cells with a central nucleus & vacuolated cytoplasm (contain the bacilli)

Russell Bodies:

Eccentric nucleus and a pink- staining cytoplasm- Look like plasma cells.

Treatment:

  1. Streptomycin (2 gm/day)
  2. Tetracyline (2 gm/day)

questions.text: A patient of suspected sinusitis has undergone CT scan of sinuses. The radiologist reports an anatomical variation of posterior ethmoid air cell lying in close proximity to optic nerve. Identify the cell.
questions.solution: There are variations of ethmoidal air cells. Haller cell is a variation of anterior ethmoid air cells and they lie in relation to orbital floor. Onodi cell is a variation of posterior ethmoid and lie in relation to optic nerve. When present they can increase the chance of complications during FESS.

questions.text: A 37 year old patient with Diabetic Ketoacidosis is admitted in ICU. On ENT examination, he is found to be having blackish mass in the nose and necrosis of skin of external nose. What is the Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Mucormycosis (rhinocerebral phycomycosis):

  1. Is an aggressive opportunistic fungal infection.
  2. Organism: Order: Mucor/Rhizopus oryzae.
  3. Predisposing factors: immunosuppressed patients, uncontrolled young diabetics.

Features:

  1. Remarkable affinity for blood vessels- arteries.
  2. Leads to extensive endothelial damage & thrombosis.

Findings:

The disease begins in the nose, invade → P.N.S → orbit → cribiform plate → meninges → brain

Typical Finding

  1. Black necrotic mass seen filling the entire nasal cavity.
  2. Erosion of the nasal septrum and the hard palate may be appreciable.

There is anesthesia over face, nose with reduced mucosal bleeding.

M.R.I. Detects early vascular and intracranial invasion.

Treatment:

  • Systemic amphotericin (Liposomal).
  • Local drainage and debridement.

choices.text: Foley's catheter placement in the nose and inflate the bulb

questions.text: A 62 year old man comes to emergency at 4.00 am with severe epistaxis and high blood pressure (180/110mm Hg). Management of hypertension started. But the epistaxis could not be controlled on anterior nasal packing and posterior nasal packing. What is the next best management of this patient
questions.solution:
The blood supply of nose. 80 % is from external carotid artery(ECA) and 20 % is from Internal carotid artery (ICA) via anterior and posterior ethmoidal arteries.

Sphenopalatine artery is the most common source of epistaxis in hypertensive patients.

Rendu Osler Weber disease, also called as hereditary hemorrhagic telengectesia presents with recurrent epistaxis. Septodermoplasty means removal of nasal mucosa and grafting with skin to treat recurrent epistaxis in this condition

choices.text: Physiological enlargement continues upto 6 years of age
Adenoidectomy is contraindicated in submucous cleft palate
Digital palpation of adenoid tissue should be avoided before removal in adenoidectomy

questions.text: Not a true statement regarding adenoids
questions.solution:
Adenoids: (Nasopharyngeal Tonsil)

Definition; Adenoids are lymphoid tissue located at the junction of nasopharyngeal roof and the posterior pharyngeal wall

Features:

  1. Are lined by ciliated columnar epithelium
  2. Have no capsule/crypts
  3. Are present at birth not visible on X-ray in children under I month of age
  4. Clinically seen by the 4th month
  5. Visible radiographically in children more than 6 month of age
  6. physiologically grow upto 6 years of age
  7. Involution after puberty

Before adenoidectomy, the adenoid mass should be palpated before surgery to confirm the diagnosis and to rule out any abnormal vessel overlying the adenoid mass

Adenoidectomy is contraindicated in hemorrhagic disorders, cleft palate, bifid uvula, hypernasality.

choices.text: Staphylococcus aureus is the causative organism

questions.text: All are true about Ludwig's angina except
questions.solution: Ludwig's angina is infection of floor of mouth= submandibular space caused due to dental infections. The bacteriology is mixed- streptococci and anaerobes. Patient has chin swelling, trismus and occasionally respiratory distress. The treatment is by incision and drainage externally deeper to mylohyoid muscle. Occasionaly, tracheostomy may be needed.

questions.text:
A 6 year old Child was operated for Adenotonsillectomy under general anaesthesia. In the evening, patient develops neck spasm and is excessively crying.

MRI Neck shows Atlantoaxial subluxation.

What is the possible diagnosis in this case
questions.solution: Grisel's syndrome, defined as subluxation of the atlanto-axial joint, not associated with trauma or bone disease, is found primarily in children. This syndrome has been observed after otolaryngologic procedures such as adenoidectomy. It presents with torticollis, neck stiffness. X-rays and computed tomography scans of the cervical spine can confirm the diagnosis. Early management, consisting of cervical immobilization and medical treatment, is considered the key factor for a satisfactory outcome. Neurological complications have been reported in the literature, ranging from mild paresthesia, clonus, to quadriplegia or acute respiratory failure and death so neurosurgical consultation is required. This complication is more common in Down's syndrome children.

choices.text: Weber Fergusson's transmaxillary approach is ideal for angiofibroma limited to nose & nasopharynx
Superior margin of sphenopalatine foramen is the most common site of origin

questions.text: All of the following are true about juvenile angiofibroma except
questions.solution:
Angiofibroma is the most common benign tumour of nasopharynx seen in adolescent males. It originates from sphenopalatine foramen. It's a highly vascular tumour. CECT scan shows Hollman Miller (=Antral) sign. Surgery is treatment of choice. Pre-op embolisation will reduce blood loss. Pre-op Estrogen, Flutamide (androgen antagonist) are helpful in reducing blood loss. Debulking or biopsy of this tumour is never done as it is a highly vascular tumour.

Tumours confined to nasopharynx can be approached through Wilson's transpalatal approach. But tumours extending to cheek would need trans- maxillary approach using weber fergusson incision.
